p: Complete closure of the peritoneum during TAPP repair is a very important step. On one hand, it prevents intestinal adhesion and obstruction caused by mesh exposure. On the other hand, it can prevent the intestine from entering the preperitoneal space ( 2, 9). Closure can be achieved with staples, tacks, running suture, or glue. Among these options, application of running suture is more time-consuming to perform but less painful to the patient ( 9). In recent years, self-anchoring barbed suture such as V-locâ„¢ has eliminated the need for knot tying and has thus been welcomed by clinicians ( 10). The efficacy and suitability of barbed sutures have been reported in the fields of gynecologic surgery ( 11, 12), plastic surgery ( 13), urology, orthopedic surgery ( 14, 15), and general surgery ( 16).
